summary: This document is a chain of emails between Assistant U.S. Attorneys and Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team regarding the logistics of reviewing physical and electronic evidence in the criminal case against Maxwell. The correspondence details negotiations over transporting evidence from FBI warehouses to the courthouse, scheduling Maxwell's presence for review, and handling materials designated as 'Highly Confidential,' including thousands of nude/partially nude images seized from Jeffrey Epstein's devices.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Partner at Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C., representing Ghislaine Maxwell. She is the primary correspondent for the defense, negotiating the terms and logistics for evidence review.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Defense attorney cc'd on the correspondence, part of Maxwell's legal team.

persons.name: Christian R Everdell
persons.context: Attorney at Cohen & Gresser LLP, part of Maxwell's defense team, cc'd on the emails.

persons.name: Bobbi C Sternheim
persons.context: Defense attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, cc'd on the correspondence.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused in the criminal case (US v. Maxwell - 20 Cr. 330). The emails discuss arrangements for her to be produced to the courthouse to review evidence with her defense team.

persons.name: Maurene
persons.context: Assistant U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York prosecuting the case. Corresponds with the defense team to arrange evidence review logistics.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned as the source of seized evidence, including electronic devices, images, and videos from his residences. His 2019 investigation by the FBI is referenced.

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge in the case (US v. Maxwell - 20 Cr. 330 (AJN/MN)). The defense mentions seeking permission from her to bring electronic devices into the courthouse.

connections.description: Menninger is the lead defense attorney representing Maxwell in the criminal case, as shown by her correspondence negotiating evidence review on Maxwell's behalf.
They are opposing counsel in the case, with Maurene representing the prosecution and Menninger the defense, coordinating on procedural and logistical matters.
The evidence being reviewed, including images and devices, was seized from Epstein's residences, and the case involves allegations of their joint criminal activity.
Both are defense attorneys on Ghislaine Maxwell's legal team, cc'd together on all correspondence.
Both are defense attorneys on Ghislaine Maxwell's legal team, collaborating on the case.

events.title: Start of Evidence Review at Courthouse
events.description: The U.S. Marshals confirm they will produce Ghislaine Maxwell to 500 Pearl Street courthouse to begin reviewing evidence with her defense team in proffer rooms on the 5th floor.

events.title: Defense Formal Request for Evidence Review
events.description: Laura Menninger sends a formal request on behalf of the defense to view all evidence and highly confidential materials in the case, initiating the logistical negotiations.

events.title: Government Production of Images
events.description: The government produced images and videos from Jeffrey Epstein's devices to the defense, with a cover letter noting that nude/partially nude images were designated 'Highly Confidential' and available for review upon request.

events.title: FBI Searches of Epstein Residences
events.description: The FBI seized numerous electronic devices, servers, laptops, and other physical evidence from Jeffrey Epstein's residences in New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands.

locations: 500 Pearl Street, New York, NY (courthouse where evidence review is scheduled)
FBI Bronx warehouse (primary storage location for physical evidence)
26 Federal Plaza, New York, NY (location of two cash evidence items)
1 St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007 (Office of the U.S. Attorney, Southern District of New York)
MDC (Metropolitan Detention Center, where Maxwell was held and previously reviewed some evidence)
keyFacts: The FBI possesses approximately 2,100 previously undisclosed electronic nude/partially nude images and videos seized from Jeffrey Epstein's devices, designated 'Highly Confidential.'
Physical evidence includes items seized from Epstein's residences such as electronic devices, plaster busts of female torsos, a stuffed dog, framed pictures, and massage tables.

The defense team sought to review all evidence with Ghislaine Maxwell present, requiring transport of evidence to the 500 Pearl Street courthouse and permission to use electronic devices for note-taking.
The prosecution agreed to produce Maxwell daily starting April 13, 2021, for evidence review in proffer rooms, with FBI agents and AUSAs present to monitor but not record defense conversations.
Evidence includes various electronic media formats (VHS tapes, cassette tapes, CDs, micro VHS) requiring specific playback equipment, which the defense agreed to provide.
